elements.content: A novel coordination polymer based on a nanosized flexible aromatic carboxylic acid ligand has been successfully synthesized by solvothermal reaction, [Cd(obda)0.5(bpy)(H2O)]·2H2O (1) (H4obda = 1,4-bis(4-oxy-1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid)benzene, bpy = 4,4′- bipyridine), exhibiting a (4,4)-connected self-penetrating pillared-layered metal–organic framework. In addition, photoluminescence was also performed on 1.
elements.clean_text: A novel coordination polymer based on a nanosized flexible aromatic carboxylic acid ligand has been successfully synthesized by solvothermal reaction, [Cd(obda)0.5(bpy)(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1) (H4obda = 1,4-bis(4-oxy-1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid)benzene, bpy = 4,4'- bipyridine), exhibiting a (4,4)-connected self-penetrating pillared-layered metal-organic framework. In addition, photoluminescence was also performed on 1.

elements.content: A novel coordination polymer [Cd(obda)0.5(bpy)(H2O)]·2H2O (1) based on a nanosized flexible aromatic carboxylic acid ligand has been successfully synthesized by solvothermal reaction. Polymer 1 exhibits a (4,4)-connected self-penetrating pillared-layered metal−organic framework in which the bpy ligand pillared mesomeric layers together to form the pillared-layered network. In addition, this coordination polymer displays modest thermal stability and solid state fluorescent emission.
elements.clean_text: A novel coordination polymer [Cd(obda)0.5(bpy)(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1) based on a nanosized flexible aromatic carboxylic acid ligand has been successfully synthesized by solvothermal reaction. Polymer 1 exhibits a (4,4)-connected self-penetrating pillared-layered metal-organic framework in which the bpy ligand pillared mesomeric layers together to form the pillared-layered network. In addition, this coordination polymer displays modest thermal stability and solid state fluorescent emission.

elements.content: In the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, the design and assembly of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with intriguing aesthetic architectures and topological features as well as their promising applications as functional materials have stimulated the interest of chemists in recent years. Topological analysis of the network has proven a powerful tool to understand and characterize the nature of the framework. One of the most reasonable methods used for constructing three-dimensional porous frameworks is to insert pillar moieties between the layers of the two-dimensional structures. This strategy has already been successfully used in the past decades, resulting in many pillared-layered porous materials being synthesized.
elements.clean_text: In the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, the design and assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with intriguing aesthetic architectures and topological features as well as their promising applications as functional materials have stimulated the interest of chemists in recent years. Topological analysis of the network has proven a powerful tool to understand and characterize the nature of the framework. One of the most reasonable methods used for constructing three-dimensional porous frameworks is to insert pillar moieties between the layers of the two-dimensional structures. This strategy has already been successfully used in the past decades, resulting in many pillared-layered porous materials being synthesized.

elements.content: Interpenetrating networks, which have been the most investigated type of entanglement, can be described as polymeric analogues of catenanes and rotaxanes. Moreover, a large number of intricate entangled structures for coordination frameworks, such as the most familiar interpenetrating nets, self-penetrating nets, polyrotaxane structures, etc., have been reported. To the best of our knowledge, among the 3D MOFs, there are many examples of interpenetrating pillared-layered metal–organic frameworks, whereas the self-penetrating networks based on pillared-layered nets have been rarely reported.
elements.clean_text: Interpenetrating networks, which have been the most investigated type of entanglement, can be described as polymeric analogues of catenanes and rotaxanes. Moreover, a large number of intricate entangled structures for coordination frameworks, such as the most familiar interpenetrating nets, self-penetrating nets, polyrotaxane structures, etc., have been reported. To the best of our knowledge, among the 3D MOFs, there are many examples of interpenetrating pillared-layered metal-organic frameworks, whereas the self-penetrating networks based on pillared-layered nets have been rarely reported.

elements.content: It is known that multicarboxylate ligands are good candidates for the construction of coordination polymers with specific structures because multicarboxylate groups can exhibit a rich variety of coordination modes. In this work, we present a novel 3D metal–organic framework (Scheme ) with a (4,4)-connected self-penetrating pillared-layered net based on the following considerations: (i) It is a tetragonal nanosized (size: about 2 nm) flexible aromatic carboxylate ligand with four carboxylate groups which may be efficient to construct intriguing structures. (ii) The flexibility around the etheric oxygen atom provides the potential to form a helical coordination polymer. (iii) The auxiliary ligand can link metal clusters into an extended 3D network with interesting topologies.
elements.clean_text: It is known that multicarboxylate ligands are good candidates for the construction of coordination polymers with specific structures because multicarboxylate groups can exhibit a rich variety of coordination modes. In this work, we present a novel 3D metal-organic framework (Scheme ) with a (4,4)-connected self-penetrating pillared-layered net based on the following considerations: (i) It is a tetragonal nanosized (size: about 2 nm) flexible aromatic carboxylate ligand with four carboxylate groups which may be efficient to construct intriguing structures. (ii) The flexibility around the etheric oxygen atom provides the potential to form a helical coordination polymer. (iii) The auxiliary ligand can link metal clusters into an extended 3D network with interesting topologies.

elements.clean_text: 1  Structural Formula of H4obda (1,4-Bis(4-oxy-1,2-benzene dicarboxylic acid)benzene)

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of H4obda and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O in the presence of 4,4′-bpy resulted in the formation of block crystals, [Cd(obda)0.5(bpy)(H2O)]·2H2O (1). The phase purity of the bulk sample was confirmed by elemental analysis and powder X-ray diffraction. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and has a three-dimensional framework (Figure a). In complex 1, each obda4– ligand links four Cd(II) ions with the μ4-η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode, and two coordinated o-phthalic acid groups of the obda4– located in trans-positions. As shown in Figure S1 of the , each cadmium atom is seven-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from obda4– (O1, O2, O4#1, and O5#1), two nitrogen atoms from two bpy (N1 and N2) ligands, and one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule (O3W) in a distorted monocapped octahedron. The obda4– ligand bridges two Cd atoms through its adjacent carboxylate groups, forming infinite helical chains along the b-axis. The helical chains have a pitch of 9.114(2) Å, and the nearest Cd···Cd distance through the obda4– ligand is 5.911(1) Å. Interestingly, there exist both left- and right-handed helices in the structures (Figure d, L′ and R′). These helical chains with opposite chirality are united alternately through obda4– ligands to exhibit a metal–organic layer (); therefore, the whole layer is mesomeric in general. The adjacent mesomeric layers are further pillared by 4,4′-bpy (N2), leading to the formation of the pillared-layered network of 1 (Figure b and ). As is usually found, in order to minimize the big void cavities and stabilize the framework, the potential voids formed by a single 3D pillared-layered network incorporate with another identical network, thus giving a 2-fold interpenetrating framework. The adjacent 3D frameworks are bridged by 4,4′-bpy (N1) ligands, resulting in the unusual 3D self-penetrating architecture (Figure a). According to previous reports, metal-organic frameworks based on a pillared-layer are common, but the 3D self-penetrating pillared-layered structure has not been reported yet. With further structural analysis, we notice that Cd(II) ions are linked by obda4– and the 4,4′-bpy into the bigger infinite left- and right-handed helical chains along the b-axis (Figure b, c and , L and R). Similarly, the bigger helical chains with opposite chirality are united alternately, and the whole framework is a mesomeric net in general. The 3D architecture is further stabilized through the hydrogen bonds between water molecules and carboxyl oxygen atoms, and the hydrogen bonding data are summarized in .
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reaction of H4obda and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O in the presence of 4,4'-bpy resulted in the formation of block crystals, [Cd(obda)0.5(bpy)(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1). The phase purity of the bulk sample was confirmed by elemental analysis and powder X-ray diffraction. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and has a three-dimensional framework (Figure a). In complex 1, each obda4- ligand links four Cd(II) ions with the μ4-η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode, and two coordinated o-phthalic acid groups of the obda4- located in trans-positions. As shown in Figure S1 of the , each cadmium atom is seven-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from obda4- (O1, O2, O4#1, and O5#1), two nitrogen atoms from two bpy (N1 and N2) ligands, and one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule (O3W) in a distorted monocapped octahedron. The obda4- ligand bridges two Cd atoms through its adjacent carboxylate groups, forming infinite helical chains along the b-axis. The helical chains have a pitch of 9.114(2) Å, and the nearest Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance through the obda4- ligand is 5.911(1) Å. Interestingly, there exist both left- and right-handed helices in the structures (Figure d, L' and R'). These helical chains with opposite chirality are united alternately through obda4- ligands to exhibit a metal-organic layer (); therefore, the whole layer is mesomeric in general. The adjacent mesomeric layers are further pillared by 4,4'-bpy (N2), leading to the formation of the pillared-layered network of 1 (Figure b and ). As is usually found, in order to minimize the big void cavities and stabilize the framework, the potential voids formed by a single 3D pillared-layered network incorporate with another identical network, thus giving a 2-fold interpenetrating framework. The adjacent 3D frameworks are bridged by 4,4'-bpy (N1) ligands, resulting in the unusual 3D self-penetrating architecture (Figure a). According to previous reports, metal-organic frameworks based on a pillared-layer are common, but the 3D self-penetrating pillared-layered structure has not been reported yet. With further structural analysis, we notice that Cd(II) ions are linked by obda4- and the 4,4'-bpy into the bigger infinite left- and right-handed helical chains along the b-axis (Figure b, c and , L and R). Similarly, the bigger helical chains with opposite chirality are united alternately, and the whole framework is a mesomeric net in general. The 3D architecture is further stabilized through the hydrogen bonds between water molecules and carboxyl oxygen atoms, and the hydrogen bonding data are summarized in .

elements.content: (a) Self-penetrating 3D structure for 1. (b) The segment of one pillared-layered metal–organic framework in 1. (c) The bigger obda-Cd-bpy helical chains. (d) The smaller obda-Cd helical chains.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Self-penetrating 3D structure for 1. (b) The segment of one pillared-layered metal-organic framework in 1. (c) The bigger obda-Cd-bpy helical chains. (d) The smaller obda-Cd helical chains.

elements.content: In order to clearly understand such a complicated architecture, the topological method is used to simplify the structure. Topologically, by regarding each Cd(II) ion and obda4– ligand as a 4-connected node, respectively, the overall 3D net can be rationalized as a binodal (4,4)-connected (it has two nonequivalent 4-coordinated nodes) framework with the point symbol of (74·82) (Figure b). Interestingly, the left- and right-handed helices of the bigger or smaller helices in this topology arrange in the cross-linkage (Figure a). Further analysis of this structure indicates that it consists of two interpenetrating (3,4)-connected nets with 3-connected Cd(II) nodes and 4-connected obda4– connectors if we take no account of the bpy ligands between two identical pillared-layered frameworks. Based on the above connection mode, the overall structure can be extended to a 3D (4,4)-connected achiral self-penetrating network. According to TOPOS topological databases, there are three examples of 2-fold arrays of this topology (TIPWIY, TIPWIY01, and VEJXAJ01), but all of them concern H-bonded networks.
elements.clean_text: In order to clearly understand such a complicated architecture, the topological method is used to simplify the structure. Topologically, by regarding each Cd(II) ion and obda4- ligand as a 4-connected node, respectively, the overall 3D net can be rationalized as a binodal (4,4)-connected (it has two nonequivalent 4-coordinated nodes) framework with the point symbol of (74⋅82) (Figure b). Interestingly, the left- and right-handed helices of the bigger or smaller helices in this topology arrange in the cross-linkage (Figure a). Further analysis of this structure indicates that it consists of two interpenetrating (3,4)-connected nets with 3-connected Cd(II) nodes and 4-connected obda4- connectors if we take no account of the bpy ligands between two identical pillared-layered frameworks. Based on the above connection mode, the overall structure can be extended to a 3D (4,4)-connected achiral self-penetrating network. According to TOPOS topological databases, there are three examples of 2-fold arrays of this topology (TIPWIY, TIPWIY01, and VEJXAJ01), but all of them concern H-bonded networks.

elements.content: (a) One topological net with the arrangement of the left- and right-handed helical chains along the b-axis in 1. (b) Self-penetrating (4,4)-connected network with (74·82) topology.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) One topological net with the arrangement of the left- and right-handed helical chains along the b-axis in 1. (b) Self-penetrating (4,4)-connected network with (74⋅82) topology.

elements.content: As shown in , the UV/vis spectrum of free ligand was recorded in reflectance mode in the solid state at room temperature. The H4obda ligand displays an absorption band between 200 and 380 nm, arising from the intraligand π–π* transitions of the aromatic rings. Photoluminescence measurements (Figure ) of complex 1 and H4obda in the solid state at room temperature show that the free H4obda ligand exhibits a broad emission band at 423 nm (λex = 327 nm), and complex 1 displays a broad emission band at 516 nm when irradiated at 362 nm which is highly red-shifted by 93 nm compared with that of the obda4– ligand. This result indicates that the fluorescence of 1 may be attributed to the mixture effects of intraligand charge transfer and LMCT from carboxylate groups to Cd(II) ions.
elements.clean_text: As shown in , the UV/vis spectrum of free ligand was recorded in reflectance mode in the solid state at room temperature. The H4obda ligand displays an absorption band between 200 and 380 nm, arising from the intraligand π-π* transitions of the aromatic rings. Photoluminescence measurements (Figure ) of complex 1 and H4obda in the solid state at room temperature show that the free H4obda ligand exhibits a broad emission band at 423 nm (λex = 327 nm), and complex 1 displays a broad emission band at 516 nm when irradiated at 362 nm which is highly red-shifted by 93 nm compared with that of the obda4- ligand. This result indicates that the fluorescence of 1 may be attributed to the mixture effects of intraligand charge transfer and LMCT from carboxylate groups to Cd(II) ions.

elements.content: Photoluminescence spectra of complex 1 and H4obda ligand in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared and characterized a rare (4,4)-connected self-penetrating pillared-layered network based on nanosized flexible aromatic carboxylic acid ligands, in which the bpy ligand pillared mesomeric layers together to form the pillared-layered network. Our research demonstrates that the employment of the nanosized H4obda ligand and the auxiliary bpy ligand is a feasible strategy to construct this self-penetrating pillared-layered network. In addition, this coordination polymer displays modest thermal stability and solid state fluorescent emission. Further studies based on this and related ligands are underway in our laboratory and will be reported in due course.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have prepared and characterized a rare (4,4)-connected self-penetrating pillared-layered network based on nanosized flexible aromatic carboxylic acid ligands, in which the bpy ligand pillared mesomeric layers together to form the pillared-layered network. Our research demonstrates that the employment of the nanosized H4obda ligand and the auxiliary bpy ligand is a feasible strategy to construct this self-penetrating pillared-layered network. In addition, this coordination polymer displays modest thermal stability and solid state fluorescent emission. Further studies based on this and related ligands are underway in our laboratory and will be reported in due course.

elements.content: Synthetic details, UV–vis spectrum of the free ligand, X-ray diffraction data, simulated powder X-ray diffraction patterns, structural details, and TGA curve, tables of crystallographic information, and topology, and crystallographic information files in CIF format (that has also been deposited as CCDC 836585 in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
